title: now I know my daughter and I have it too
text:

Jenny was shocked when her son, Jason, was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes 12 years ago. Jason was 38 years old and had always been fit and healthy.

He had two young children and a successful job as the manager of a large manufacturing company.

He was in the prime of life, splitting his time between his job in Germany and his home in the UK.

But his health deteriorated rapidly and, within months, he was insulin-dependant.

Jason had private healthcare via his job and had been sent for several tests in Germany.

One of these was a blood test that came back with a diagnosis of a genetic condition called haemochromatosis.

The UK and Ireland are a hotspot for the condition haemochromatosis – so much so that it’s also known as the ‘Celtic curse’.

‘My first thought was, “Well, that’s a bit of a mouthful,”’ says Jenny.

‘I’d never heard of it before, and no one in the family had ever been diagnosed with it.'

'But I was surprised to discover how common it is, and that people are dying of it, yet many doctors in the UK don’t seem to know about it at all.’

Haemochromatosis is a hereditary genetic disorder that causes the body to absorb too much iron from food.

That iron then builds up to toxic levels, damaging organs, joints and soft tissues.

If it’s left untreated, it can cause diabetes, arthritis , liver cirrhosis and failure, heart failure and several cancers.

Although it was once thought of as a rare condition, the latest research estimates that one in 200 Brits suffers from the condition, but only one in 5,000 is diagnosed.

‘Awful things began to fall into place as I read about the effect it has on the body,’ says Jenny.

‘My mother, sister and uncle had all died from liver failure – none of them had been a heavy drinker and the cause had never been determined.'

'I’m now sure they died of the condition.’

Jason’s consultant advised Jenny and other family members to go straight to their GP for a blood test to check their level of ferritin – the blood-cell protein that carries iron around the body.

Haemochromatosis is still widely underdiagnosed, partly because of a lack of awareness in some areas of the medical profession.

Symptoms such as joint pain, fatigue, weakness and irregular periods can easily be put down to other conditions, and as a result many sufferers can go for years without being diagnosed and treated.

A lucky diagnosis

Jenny was fortunate.

‘The doctor I saw had an intern with him, and they were intrigued when I told them about Jason’s diagnosis.'

'He said, “Gosh, that’s different – I’m going to follow it up and talk to my colleagues.”

'I just thank God it was him I was booked in to see that day, because my cousin went for a test and his doctor told him not to worry, saying haemochromatosis was something that affected only people who drank too much – it was ridiculous.’

A test confirmed that both Jenny and her daughter Helen, then 33, had the condition.

As Helen was pregnant, her treatment was put on hold, but Jenny and Jason were referred to their local haematology units right away.

Healthy ferritin levels are below 300 ng/mL (nanograms per millilitre of blood) for men, and below 150 ng/mL for women.

Jenny’s levels were sky-high, at 2,000 ng/mL, and Jason’s were over 3,000 ng/mL.

The treatment for haemochromatosis is very similar to donating blood: a procedure called a venesection removes a pint of blood at a time through a thick needle.

This contains 200mg of iron and forces the body to use stored iron to build new red blood cells.

Jenny began to have a venesection every fortnight, while Jason needed one every week.

Although they were being treated in different hospitals miles apart – Jason in Warwick and Jenny in Bristol – it was a comfort to her to know they were going through the same thing.

‘It was quite invasive and difficult to fit round my job working with people with disabilities, but I was amazed by how much less tired I felt after a few sessions,’ says Jenny.

‘I’d been on awful arthritis tablets for years, but was able to give them up as my symptoms improved.’

Although Jenny began to feel better, things got worse for Jason.

On a work trip to China, he picked up a food-borne strain of hepatitis and became gravely ill.

Four and half years after his diagnosis, his liver began to fail.

Although he was put on the list to receive a transplant, doctors advised he would be unlikely to receive a match because of his size – he was unusually tall, at 6ft 5in – and also had a rare blood type.

At 43 years old, Jason was hospitalised.

‘It was extremely difficult at the end,’ recalls Jenny.

(Image: Getty Images)

‘He just didn’t want to be in hospital and kept trying to leave to go back to work, but he was very ill by that point.'

'In fact, the nurses had a problem keeping him there, so in the end they sedated him.'

'They said it’d help his organs repair and they’d be able to work on him without him knowing.'

'It seemed like the best thing, but it was very, very hard.’

For eight weeks, Jenny sat by her son’s bedside as he lay unconscious.

She tried to stay strong for his children, who were 12 and 16 at the time.

Unfortunately, Jason’s condition didn’t improve and no donor was found.

Doctors decided to bring him round so his family could say goodbye.

‘He couldn’t talk because of the breathing tubes in his mouth, but he maintained his sense of humour right to the end, smiling when the nurses made jokes,’ she says.

Four days later, Jason died peacefully, with his family around him.

His death certificate gives haemochromatosis as the primary cause.

‘You don’t expect to lose a child,’ says Jenny.

‘That’s the bit that was so devastating – it’s the wrong order of things.

'He was my boy and it was shattering.

'People ask me how I cope, but you just wake up every day and get out of bed because you have to.

'As the mum and the oldest member of the family, you just have to stay strong for everybody.’

An avoidable death

This year, the family should have been celebrating Jason’s 50th birthday.

Instead, they’ll be visiting his grave.

Jenny and Helen now have venesections every 12 weeks and will need to continue with this treatment forever.

If they continue to lead a healthy lifestyle, there’s nothing to stop them living a long life despite having haemochromatosis – a fact that makes it even tougher for Jenny to accept Jason’s death.

‘It’s devastating to think that a simple blood test could have saved Jason’s life,’ she says.

‘In France, where rates of the condition are much lower than in the UK, babies are tested at birth, meaning many sufferers are spared the horrible complications by having early treatment.’

(Image: Getty Images/EyeEm)

Jenny continues, ‘People have blood tests every day, and it would be easy to check for haemochromatosis at the same time.'

'A specialist told me that checking ferritin levels would only cost an extra 50p.'

'When you think of the price of years of arthritis or diabetes medication, or cancer and heart-failure treatment, that is nothing – it’s criminal not to test people.’

These days, Jenny campaigns to raise awareness of the condition she believes has killed many members of her family.

Slowly but surely, awareness is growing.

In July, MPs debated ways to tackle the issue of significant under-diagnosis of haemochromatosis and new research has recently been funded.

She’s pleased about that.

‘I’m on a mission to get doctors to wake up,’ she says.

‘Helen and I are so aware that, in death, Jason gave us life, because we may not have known about our own condition until it was too late.'

'Nothing will bring back my son, but I hope his death won’t be for nothing.’

- For more about haemochromatosis, or to donate, go to Haemochromatosis.org.uk
description: Jenny Lees, 75, has lost a number of family members to haemochromatosis – a widely under-diagnosed blood condition thought to be Britain’s most common genetic disorder…
